p: Diabetes and diabetes-related complications decrease life quality and present huge financial burdens for individuals and families, as well as for the health systems and economies of countries. There are many national and worldwide diabetes prevention programs focusing on preventing or delaying the onset of diabetes and its complications. While there is no effective intervention to prevent type 1 diabetes, there is strong evidence that primary prevention of type 2 diabetes can be effective. The most efficient strategy for prevention or, at least, delay of type 2 diabetes onset/development is feasible in many ethnic groups by lifestyle modification or administration of some pharmacological agents [ 18, 19].
